t: Job 21
Job Replies: The Wicked Do Prosper
Then*p Job answered and said:
“Keep*pn listening to my words, and*ld let this be your comfort.
Bear*ln with me, and I will speak, and*ld after I have spoken, mock on.
As*ln for me, is my complaint against man? Why*ld should I not be impatient?
Look*ln at me and be appalled, and*ld lay your hand over your mouth.
When*ln I remember, I am dismayed, and*ld shuddering seizes my flesh.
Why*ln do the wicked live, reach*ld old age, and grow mighty in power?
Their*ln offspring are established in their presence, and*ld their descendants before their eyes.
Their*ln houses are safe from fear, and*ld no rod of God is upon them.
Their*ln bull breeds without fail; their*ld cow calves and does not miscarry.
They*ln send out their little boys like a flock, and*ld their children dance.
They*ln sing to the tambourine and the lyre and*ld rejoice to the sound of the pipe.
They*ln spend their days in prosperity, and*ld in peace they go down to Sheol.
They*ln say to God, ‘Depart from us! We*ld do not desire the knowledge of your ways.
What*ln is the Almighty, that we should serve him? And*ld what profit do we get if we pray to him?’
Behold,*ln is not their prosperity in their hand? The*ld counsel of the wicked is far from me.
“How*pn often is it that the lamp of the wicked is put out? That*ld their calamity comes upon them? That*ld God distributes pains in his anger?
That*ln they are like straw before the wind, and*ld like chaff that the storm carries away?
You*ln say, ‘God stores up their iniquity for their children.’ Let*ld him pay it out to them, that they may know it.
Let*ln their own eyes see their destruction, and*ld let them drink of the wrath of the Almighty.
For*ln what do they care for their houses after them, when*ld the number of their months is cut off?
Will*ln any teach God knowledge, seeing*ld that he judges those who are on high?
One*ln dies in his full vigor, being*ld wholly at ease and secure,
his*ln pails full of milk and*ld the marrow of his bones moist.
Another*ln dies in bitterness of soul, never*ld having tasted of prosperity.
They*ln lie down alike in the dust, and*ld the worms cover them.
“Behold,*pn I know your thoughts and*ld your schemes to wrong me.
For*ln you say, ‘Where is the house of the prince? Where*ld is the tent in which the wicked lived?’
Have*ln you not asked those who travel the roads, and*ld do you not accept their testimony
that*ln the evil man is spared in the day of calamity, that*ld he is rescued in the day of wrath?
Who*ln declares his way to his face, and*ld who repays him for what he has done?
When*ln he is carried to the grave, watch*ld is kept over his tomb.
The*ln clods of the valley are sweet to him; all*ld mankind follows after him, and*ld those who go before him are innumerable.
How*ln then will you comfort me with empty nothings? There*ld is nothing left of your answers but falsehood.”
